answers.text: a class which does not belong to other classes

qas.question: Under what approach does an axiom impede a set of all sets which do not belong to themselves?
Under Von Neumann's approach can a class of all sets that do not belong to themselves be constructed?

answers.text: class of all sets which do not belong to themselves can be constructed, but it is a proper class and not a set.

context: The second approach to the problem took as its base the notion of class, and defines a set as a class which belongs to other classes, while a proper class is defined as <a0_0>a class which does not belong to other classes<a0_0/>. Under the <a1_0>Zermelo–Fraenkel<a1_0/> approach, the axioms impede the construction of a set of all sets which do not belong to themselves. In contrast, under the von Neumann approach, the <a2_0>class of all sets which do not belong to themselves can be constructed, but it is a proper class and not a set.
